'''xmonad''' is a [[tiling window manager]] for the [[X Window System]], written in the [[Functional programming|functional programming language]] [[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]].
'''xmonad''' is a [[tiling window manager]] for the [[X Window System]], written in the [[Functional programming|functional programming language]] [[Haskell (programming language)|Haskell]].
â
Begun in March 2007, it is similar to [[dwm]], [[larswm]], [[Stumpwm|StumpWM]] and other members of the tiling window manager family, in that it strives to make it possible for the user to productively manage windows without the use of the [[Mouse (computing)|mouse]]. xmonad is [[Package management system|distributed]] on a wide range of [[Unix-like]] operating systems, including [[Arch Linux]], [[Debian]], <!-- [[Fedora Linux]]<ref>[http://fedorapeople.org/~ynemoy/xmonad/]</ref>,--> [[Ubuntu (Linux distribution)|Ubuntu]], [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]], [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]] and [[OpenBSD]].
+
Begun in March 2007, it is similar to [[dwm]], [[larswm]], [[Stumpwm|StumpWM]] and other members of the tiling window manager family, in that it strives to make it possible for the user to productively manage windows without the use of the [[Mouse (computing)|mouse]]. xmonad is [[Package management system|distributed]] on a wide range of [[Unix-like]] operating systems, including [[Arch Linux]], [[Debian]], <!-- [[Fedora Linux]]<ref>[http://fedorapeople.org/~ynemoy/xmonad/]</ref>,--> [[Ubuntu (operating system)|Ubuntu]], [[Gentoo Linux|Gentoo]], [[FreeBSD]], [[NetBSD]] and [[OpenBSD]].
While originally a [[Clone (computer science)|clone]] of dwm (derivative in areas such as default keybindings), xmonad supports features not available to dwm users<ref>{{cite web
While originally a [[Clone (computer science)|clone]] of dwm (derivative in areas such as default keybindings), xmonad supports features not available to dwm users<ref>{{cite web
